displayed_text: Patient: I know it. I know it. Um in a perfect world. Doctor: Mm hmm. Patient: If I’ve been trying to say how I’m going to ask this question. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’ve never had any difficulty asking questions, not that it will ever go away, in a perfect world Doctor: Yeah. Patient: these three, four, five, six session of chemo – Doctor: Um, hmm. Patient: - what would be the best result in your opinion? Doctor: Well that you feel better, the PSA goes down to zero and the next imaging scans are rock stable. That’d be a homerun. It won’t ever really go away you know these things don’t change. Patient: The metastatic areas we see on the bones… Doctor: They’re there forever. Patient: They’re there…

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year
Which of the following best describe you.Other: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Other

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: But sometimes it's vacation and special events and life. Patient: . Right now. Family Member: Okay, what if he goes on chemo- Doctor: Uh huh. Family Member: How is his reaction or side effects kind of differ from the way they are right now. Doctor: Well, that's, you know, for Xtandi, it's the potential tiredness, a little balance issues, none of which has plagued you, but chemo is more chemo usual chemo type of things, like hair thinning or hair loss. Family Member: We don’t worry about that. Doctor: You can get neuropathy, you know, over time, which is numbness and tingling. Patient: I can’t get more than I got. Doctor: Well, I'm hoping it's not that bad, you're stable, but you know, if it gets much worse you're not even eligible for the trial. The other parts are, you know, we watch the liver function, we check by blood test. Some people get a weird taste in their mouth, not necessarily metallic, but just doesn't taste right. Family Member: In other words, when he eats it’s not going to be as wonderful.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So, you know, probably, I mean, both of these probably two weeks. Patient: Did you get the results I emailed you. The DNA. Doctor: Yes. So, I got back the germline genetics testing. So this that this testing, well, do you remember? Tell me what you remember about that testing. The saliva testing that you did Patient: He was going to try to figure out um.. if this was hereditary or something. Doctor: Right, exactly. So that was negative for the, for the cancer causing gene. So that was negative. That is a different that's different than this. Patient: That’s different than this. Doctor: Yeah, because this this genotype that we're looking for- it does not predispose you to cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: This is something that's very common in the population. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We just think that these people are more likely to respond to antioxidants.

Patient: So and - Doctor: Okay. We’ll get a plan. Patient: So it was described to be by the nurses. It’s the last time they tweak the aim if they’re not exactly satisfied with the - Doctor: Mm hmm, it might be IMRT, you know sort of image modulated radiation therapy. Patient: Don’t know that. Doctor: Okay, so I can check with him. I know what M___s going to do is try to have you sign a form so we could see if you could be eligible for this other study. Um, it is a pill drug. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, a biologic, so not a chemo. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um many, many arms of this trial. It’s like the octopus study. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Where there’s a lot. But you’re basically taking a pill. There is a pathway that’s always screwed up with prostate cancer. This sort of tackles that pathway.

Patient: Right. Doctor: That’s not a whole lot, uh, for change. And your scans have not shown any major change. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know? The ones she did in, uh, end of November or December, whenever you saw her last. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, so based on that, I wouldn’t change anything. I think you should stick with, uh, the Lupron should be continued and the bone medication. Are they doing both of those? Family Member: Yeah. Today he gets- he gets his next Lupron February twelfth. Doctor: Okay. And what about the (Xgeva) Family Member: Uh-uh. Doctor: That may be helpful. So I’ll, uh, send a note to her. There is a bone-strengthening medication. Family Member: He’s seen a, uh, do you need to see your dentist before you-? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. That kind of stuff. But, uh, but it can be very helpful, especially because the hormone therapy all this time has, can weaken the bones. So, so this may be something that will help, uh, and sometimes it can help with the bone pain, too, uh. You know? So I think all around it’s a good idea to get that started.

Patient: Good. Family Member: We like him very much. (Chuckles) Doctor: Okay, anything else? Patient: That’s it. Family Member: That’s it. Doctor: Let me see what we have in here in terms of just follow-up. So he’s already set up for his shot. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So January thirtieth. Family Member: Okay, right. Doctor: So everything else that we’re going to add up now will be related to the study. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So you know all of this is, one, you have to be okeydokey with the plan. Two, there’s no emergency, but I always like to stay ahead of your cancer. Family Member: Ahead of the game. Yeah. Doctor: So that’s why we’re having this discussion. Hum, and, three, you know, you don’t like this, then we move onto pills. You know? And there I have different trials, different options, and things like that. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It’s just that I always like to try to get this one in. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Because we have the opportunity. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So here we are. (pause3sec) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Do you want the paperwork to read?

Doctor: Woah! Doctor: Makes you conscious, doesn’t it? (Laughs) Patient: Right. I forgot they was in here. Doctor: Oh good for you. Oh you made one? Healthcare Professional: Oh yeah I put it. Doctor: Okay, okay I see. Patient: They ain’t doin’ any… (pause4sec) Doctor: And pain wise I have to give you the one hundred eighty right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I think you’ve reminded me after now enough that (laughs) Healthcare Professional: I think he’s on morphine sixty? Doctor: Is he authorized for the Okay. Patient: Oh out here?

Patient: Mm, hmm. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have a one month version, we have a three month version, we have a year long version. We could start with the one-month version just to make sure things are okay. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: And I could ask my nurse to get authorization for that. So I don’t think we could just give it to you right now. Patient: Right. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I think she has to get it improved from you insurance company and then you could come back in a week or two and get it. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then you’ll have a consult. Family Member: Mm,hmm.

Family Member: Every time you go there I mean you can’t get in to see him. I mean you’re there for hours. Doctor: I B___ City? Patient: B___ City, yeah. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So… Patient: So yeah I’d rather see somebody… Family Member: We burned that bridge. Patient: I’d rather see somebody… yeah can’t go back to that. Doctor: I know because honestly then maybe and that probably should get fixed – Family Member: Yes. Doctor: - even if we make decisions about chemotherapy or something we cannot afford to have a major source of infection sitting right there. So definitely that will hold up a lot of our decisions about other treatments for sure.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay let me try and I’m going to… Patient: Take a look. Doctor: Did they put it in yet? Family Member: No. Doctor: Let me at least have it uploaded. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So she’ll get it put into our system that way we have a door closes]]. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Even otherwise. How are you feeling? Patient: Same. I mean normal. Doctor: Arms? Patient: Oh that’s the same too. I do have a question there because I have an appointment with the neurologist.

Family Member: Mm. Doctor: But the, yeah, so the, I can print this out for you too, just so that you have it for your records. The testing to see if you have the hereditary risk of cancer was negative. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright, so of these options, what I think is reasonable, and what I think is not reasonable. Observation for you actually, I don't think is reasonable. You're a pretty healthy guy. You're a pretty healthy guy. And you don't have any comorbidities. You know, I would expect you to live if you didn't have prostate cancer, I would expect to live for at least another 10 years. So I think that we should do something more than observation, right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So this one would not be my first choice. Intermittent hormone therapy, I think if you wanted to go for a standard approach, like what everybody else is doing, I think that that is a very reasonable option. The downside is that you would be exposed to hormone therapy. And when we get to, if you ever get to this phase where you have metastatic disease where we can see your lymph nodes or see disease in the bones, you get started on hormonal hormone therapy anyways. So what usually happens in this approach is that you're getting it every six months. And, you know, maybe you get it for six months and you’re off of it for two years, maybe three years together for six months or a year, go for six months necessarily. This is certainly not a bad option. This is the standard option. This is what we consider the standard of care, like what's most widely accepted. And this could be an option now or later. You know, having talked to you before. I think what we should maybe try and do first is see if you'd be eligible and if you have this genotype for the MAP study. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You mentioned before that you were taking a number of supplements and you know, we're interested in natural products and how they may help your risk of cancer or cancer progression. Doctor: So, I think that that would be a reasonable first approach to see and hear. You know, first to see if you're eligible for the study- Patient: Okay. Doctor: -and then, get the genetic testing for the study. And then if you are, join that study. Patient: Okay.

Patient: I – yeah. Whatever. Doctor: I got a great idea! Patient: What? Doctor: Let’s do this! Family Member: I gotta get out. Doctor: Right. (Laughs) Patient: What? Doctor: Let’s get M__ to just talk hard, here’s what gotta do, thinkin’ movin’ forward. Patient: Who is M_? Doctor: M_ S_!!!! You know M_! She’s the research nurse! You’ve talked to her a thousand times already! Patient: Ohhhh. Family Member: She come back every day.

Patient: Is what the trick is? Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Uh, anyway, I’ll, I’ll- Patient: Yeah. If you get a chance. Doctor: Will think about that. Okay. Patient: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. So I will try to get a hold of you Friday. Patient: Uh-Uh. Okay. All right. Sounds good. Doctor: I’ll let them know we’re done so they can- Patient: All right. Doctor: I don’t know where the other camera is. Patient: There’s one there, and one there. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: I hope, I hope they’re as generous with hotels as the last one. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: They had some nice places on that list. You know? Doctor: Yeah. There’s, there’s some nice places on this list too. Patient: Called the T___. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Oh that’s a nice. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. That place is really nice. Doctor: Yeah. But I think the nice part with that is they you know people running out Patient: Yeah. Doctor: at Hopkins know Patient: Yeah. Doctor: this is a toll on people coming up every week.
